pullRequest.body:
A couple of results about `DirectedOn` and Pi products:

- When a set of cross sections is `DirectedOn`, then the projection onto a fibre is  `DirectedOn`
- For each element `i` in the base space, let `d i` be a subset of the fibre at `i`. Then the product of the `d i` is `DirectedOn`.

We also give pairwise product versions of these results.

Inspired by #15412

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

-->

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ DirectedOn.mono_comp`
`+ fst`
`+ pi`
`+ prod`
`+ proj`
`+ snd`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Also, could you do a check for double spaces and remove them ? I've seen a few, but it's probably easier for you to check rather than me opening comments from each of them.

Thanks!
bors d+

:v: mans0954 can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Could you instead add the following right after [Directed.mono_comp](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Directed.html#Directed.mono_comp) and use it here?
```lean
theorem DirectedOn.mono_comp {r : α → α → Prop} {rb : β → β → Prop} {g : α → β} {s : Set α}
    (hg : ∀ ⦃x y⦄, r x y → rb (g x) (g y)) (hf : DirectedOn r s) : DirectedOn rb (g '' s) :=
  directedOn_image.mpr (hf.mono hg)
```
Also, I think this should simply be called `DirectedOn.proj` or `DirectedOn.eval`, double namespaces tend to be unusable.
Done, thanks.

Could you allow for any `s : Set ι` instead of `univ`? 

Also, I would call this `DirectedOn.set_pi`, or even `DirectedOn.pi`

@ADedecker I'm failing to imagine the statement you want proved here? I assume you mean something like `DirectedOn (· ≤ ·) (Set.pi  s d)` - but given x and y in `Set.pi  s d` I think one still needs to find `z`  in `Set.pi  s d` such that `x i ≤ z i` and `y i ≤ z i` for all `i` in `ι`, not just in `s`?
You're right, this was a dumb suggestion. The worst part is I remember "thinking" about it, but clearly I just made something up. Sorry for that.
Easily done! Particularly when switching between lean programming and mathematical thinking.

Could you add docstrings to the lemmas below saying explicitly that they are applicable to product orders thanks to definitional equality (if that is indeed the case)?

Also, is there a reason to allow for non-le relations in this case but not for indexed products? My guess is it work as well.

> Also, is there a reason to allow for non-le relations in this case but not for indexed products? My guess is it work as well.

I thought about that, but wasn't sure how to set it up. I've pushed something now. How does it look?

The previous `LE` results can be recovered from the new results as:
```
variable {ι : Type*} {α : ι → Type*} [∀ i, LE (α i)]

example {d : Set (Π i, α i)} (hd : DirectedOn (· ≤ ·) d) (i : ι) :
    DirectedOn (· ≤ ·) ((fun a => a i) '' d) := proj _ hd _

example {d : (i : ι) → Set (α i)} (hd : ∀ (i : ι), DirectedOn (· ≤ ·) (d i)) :
    DirectedOn (· ≤ ·) (Set.pi  Set.univ d) := pi _ (fun i => hd i)
```

As I just checked, that last line still work if you replace `(fun i => hd i)` by `hd` ? This seems to indicate the definitional equalities seem to be working perfectly, so I'd say this is perfect.

Would you mind adding documentations to pretty much every of these lemmas saying "Note that this lemma applies directly to product types with the product order thanks to nice definitional equalities" or something like that? Just so that people finding them on the documentation don't rule them out because of complicated statements.
Likewise, I think this shouldn't be namespaced.
I think this should be named `DirectedOn.set_prod` or even `DirectedOn.prod`.
Could you use `DirectedOn.mono_comp` here again? That's not much shorter of course, but it's a bit cleaner.
Same here

Here's a nice trick: the choose tactic allows you to break out `hf` into different sub-hypotheses (well actually it doesn't distinguish between `f` and `hf` either, it justs splits as long as you ask for), so you can avoid having a bunch of "and"s under a forall. That makes the rest of the proof look much cleaner:
```suggestion
  choose f hfd haf hbf using fun i => hd i (a i) (ha i trivial) (b i) (hb i trivial)
  exact ⟨f, fun i _ => hfd i, haf, hbf⟩
```
I think this should be left implicit: the most common case will be product orders where it will be inferred, and otherwise named arguments should work in our favor.

As much as I like `aesop`, I think using it here is a bit overkill.
```suggestion
  obtain ⟨r₁, hdr₁, hpr₁, hqr₁⟩ := h₁ _ hpd.1 _ hqd.1
  obtain ⟨r₂, hdr₂, hpr₂, hqr₂⟩ := h₂ _ hpd.2 _ hqd.2
  exact ⟨⟨r₁, r₂⟩, ⟨hdr₁, hdr₂⟩, ⟨hpr₁, hpr₂⟩, ⟨hqr₁, hqr₂⟩⟩
```

But maybe I'm too infected by angle-brackets, so feel free to ignore if you disagree.

pullRequest.title: feat(Order/Directed): DirectedOn and products

source.title: feature(Order/ScottContinuity): Scott Continuity on product spaces
